reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have not reviewed a product until now, but I feel like this game in particular could use one, especially since I've found it to be very entertaining (when I finally got into a game, that is). This review is based on only two games that I've played in, so people who have played Wild Warfare for a lot longer than I have will probably be able to form a better review than the one you're reading right now.

This review has been slightly edited in regards to the game now being free to play but many of the issues still stand currently.

I've found Wild Warfare heavily reminding me of arena-shooters such as Unreal tournament, and that in itself brings back many happy memories, memories that I hope to make in Wild Warfare. Unfortunately there are a few issues in the current version of this game that prevent me from outright recommending it to anyone, and I hope these issues get fixed soon (or at the very least tweaked to be a little more bearable then they are now).

Starting with some of the pros I found in my short playthrough:

Map selection in Wild Warfare is small, but the maps do feel nice and and are well-designed (for the most part, there is one exception with the current CTF map with jump-pads at the back of each base, which makes for relatively quick captures and seems to be very infuriating to players, going off by what I see in their discussion board). The maps aren't too large as to make finding other players impossible and there are several jump-pads around the maps, which speeds up travelling around these maps significantly, so you shouldn't be without someone to shoot at for long in a game.

The music in the game sounds nice, the artwork in the game is cute and inviting. Not much more to say here (mostly because I know next to nothing about music and art).

One of the things I especially liked was the fact that when you level up, you can get keys to open crates, which makes a huge difference (to me, anyway). I really hope this stays, as it offers some customization options for free to play players, which this game is supposedly going to be, though I don't see the option for free to play on steam yet (Though it seems you can play a browser-based version for free at Hyperhippo.ca).

One thing to note to parents looking at this game: Yes, there is no blood and gore or foul language, so if for some reason you want to introduce a young one to shooters, then you probably want to pick this up. Bear in mind though that this isn't accounting for any foul words that may come from strangers online.

Has a decent variety of game modes with another on the way it seems.

Seems to perform well on computers that have low specs (I have one terrible rig, so finding games that run on it is a blessing).

Onto some cons I found while playing:

What you see is what you get on your class. There are currently three classes in the game, and each has a different weapon; The engineer has a wrench, the heavy has a minigun, and the striker has a burst assault rifle. That's it. That's all they got. Weapon selection is not very big at this moment in time, though it does make it relatively simple to easily glance at a furry critter's hands (paws, for those that want to get technical with it) and look at the only weapon they have.

Bullet speed is slow, which slows down the pace of the game quite a bit for the firearms at anything beyond 'medium-range', which may not be a particularly bad thing as it encourages you to get closer to land shots easier, but a slight increase in bullet speed would be welcome.

There's no way to crouch in the game, which I didn't find as too big a deal since weapons don't have any recoil at all, but it's something to be noted.

You can't make your own servers at this time.

There are exploitable bugs and glitches that can seriously break the flow of a game (there appears to be an auto-firing bug, which happened quite a bit for me), which I hope are fixed soon.

Servers aren't the best, you'll see players floating in the sky and you can get hit by the engineer's wrench when they're a few feet away and nowhere near melee range. You won't have to worry about the servers, however, unless you can find a game with people. Not many people are currently online at a time, so it'll take awhile for you to find a server with people playing on it sometimes. However, with the game now being free to play, I expect a few servers with people in them, so perhaps the game population will increase in due time.

Classes aren't balanced at this time, with the heavy being underpowered, the striker being balanced, and the engineer being overpowered (at least, when it came to CTF, unsure of how the engineer performs in the other modes).

While not a con, something I'd like to bring up is competition from other games. When reading about the game it sounds quite a bit like Team Fortress two, doesn't it? It even has hats. Yes, I'm aware Team Fortress two doesn't have vehicles but otherwise it seems like it'll be very much the same. Wild Warfare also references Team Fortress two through an achievement, so it's safe to say that they are at least aware of Team fortress two (then again you'd have to be under a rock not to). While I don't expect it to ever overtake Team Fortress two in terms of popularity, I do think it'll at least get a stable community of players, especially since it's also a free to play game that has a slight Team Fortress two vibe at first glance. I'm looking forward to how things will turn out!

Well, that's about all I can say from my two games worth of experience. As stated earlier I cannot recommend the game in its current state, however I do enjoy playing it and would like to in the future. I can't give a definite answer to if you should buy this game or not, but currently, I am content with most of the things I see, and I only hope this game gets better.

This is what you'd get if you combined Amazing World with Team Fortress 2. It's an odd mix, and a fresh feeling to play something so different. I expected it to be a silly, 30 minute game that I'd regret installing... Instead, I played until my hands hurt. That doesn't happen often.

You'd be surprised how much fun it is to play as either a squirrel, a bunny, or a big, fat bear with a gigantic machine gun. It resembles TF2 in a lot of ways, sure, but not enough to feel the EXACT same. It has its own definite combat touch to it, and yet, it's still under-developed thus far.

Yes, dearest review readers. At this time, it's buggy. The loadout boxes and key thing is weird, and almost seems rushed. The CPU plant enemies don't exactly play nice, nor do they act as they should, (I doubt they're supposed to move that fast,) and finally, the lag is ridiculous! But, all in all, excellent gaming experience in my opinion!

It's got potential; a lot more potential than certain games lurking around Steam, and for what it's worth, I can already tell that this is gonna be one addicting game later on down the road. How could it not? You get beaten to death by bunnies, shoot at roadents, capture flags, and go wild!

The game is pretty fun! Don't look at the playtime, I got more playtime, like 5 hours, due the fact i was playing via web version. First you got 3 unique classes which totally difference from each other, the levels are not many, still early access, but they are quite fun. You have many obstacles as some berry like creatures to chase and eat you, exploding crates which you can use to blow the enemy, power ups, hot streams which shoot you up, similar to jumps on quake 3 which makes game pretty fun.

Deathmatch is fun, because of the neutral enemies, those are quite nasty and hard to run from, but they gives you points too, so if you are having skills, you can win the game counting on them.

Capture the flag, there you have yuge robot to control which helps you to support the team or guard your flag, you have speed ups many places to barricade yourself  and guard, many place to stuck enemy into a trap between exploding crates.

Team Deathmatch, again differs from usual gameplay, you should just check the game and see that it looks more fun than the videos.

What is expected.
As far as i know new classes, maps, customizations and friend invitations are planned. So I'm expecting good stuff from the game now.

Bad things here.
The only drawbacks, the game crashes at me somehow before joining, happened several times. No clan-tags and avatar support and nothing was mentioned for those. Needs more perks, double damage, double health, etc, which will really make the gameplay more intensive.
No LAN support or dedicated server announced.

Pay to play - pay to win?
Nah, the game at it's current stage is free to play and has no microtrasactions, they stated that they are planning to add payment methods and I hope that will not overpower some players compared to another when product is finished in the future, because it will disbalance it greatly which is not cool thing for shooter.

Gameplay goes well!
The game plays smooth, characters are not lagging out or glitching into objects despite the edgy areas, it has nice dynamics, movements are good, aiming is very nicely done. Sometimes it takes quite much of skills to bring down your enemy as they dodges your shooting pretty good too.
The only thing that nagged me about shooting from higher place is that your shooting hits the ground so you should expose yourself from your cover to kill someone, still that is not something bad, you should just pay more caution on your cover then.

I recommend the game, especially because lack of pay to joy, it is pretty fun in the current state and I really hope they to keep it that way.

♦ Slow

Early Access Review

Horribly buggy and hasn't update in 2 or so years after watching a youtube video on it. Like TF2 dumbed down, basically. Each class has one weapon, raccoon 'striker' shoots 3 shots 1 damage each and can aim down sights 4 hp, rabbit 'engineer' has a wrench and whacks people with it for 2 damage each and has 3 hp may or may not run fast, bear 'heavy' that has a minigun that can overheat with bullets that deal 1 damage each moves slowly and has 8 hp.

There are different modes but you can't mode select, it choses for you. FFA, team deathmatch, and capture the flag from what I saw. Vehicles are 'level locked' which basically means if you didn't play enough matches before entering the match with a vehicle you can't use it. The game feels floaty, I could barely hit someone going up a ramp in a straight line.

In the capture the flag mode, people can pick up a speed power up before picking the flag up to get it away faster, but not with the flag equipped. You can't drop things either, as far as I can tell from the 'rebindable keys.' There is no chat, may have removed it? In FFA mode there was a snail I picked up as far as I could tell did nothing, and since I couldn't drop it, I threw myself into the lava.

The AI in the game is dumb, and if you sneak up behind them you have a 50 50 they won't turn around and attack you back, but since most of this game is killing people by sneaking up behind them (3 shot burst for quick kill as a striker, hitting them with the wrench as the bunny, doing a quick gun down as a heavy) there's rarely a time to pick a fair fight by going up in front about it due to low HP and high damage.

The only redeeming factor I could see is the cosmetics, which you randomly got per level some keys to open crates that dropped from enemies. I didn't see a cash shop other than the DLC they had on the store, which wasn't too highly priced either. I guess the main reason this hasn't been updated in 2 years is due to no money and being FTP, but still isn't worth playing imo.

In the short time I've played this game, I can tell you a lot about it.

Wild Warfare is a FPS game featuring multiple classes, all inspired by cartoonish animal characters. Players participate in team-based objectives and large maps, with multiple game modes and a different animal for every class type.

This game is a diamond in the rough that REALLY shines. It could do with a few more updates like new maps, gamemodes and maybe characters even though they are pretty perfect already. They are well balanced and each have their strong suits. The customization options are absolutely brilliant. Facepaint, bow ties, top hats and many more and they're pretty easy to unlock to! Wild Warfare isn't without flaws, (which game isn't?) but the satisfaction of killing another player is immense and pays off really well. It nails that one more go feeling and can get quite intense in certain gamemodes.
Talking about gamemodes, some of them could be improved. The worst is the Snail Gamemode where a player can collect the snail which gives them one point per second. This can be quite an annoying mode because people always win by a landslide. So watch out for that.

Overall this unusual and unique FPS game is a great game to spice up your free time. It's nowhere near a P2W either. You'll be on the edge of your seats in the intense battles. What are you waiting for? Go download that game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have not reviewed a product until now, but I feel like this game in particular could use one, especially since I've found it to be very entertaining (when I finally got into a game, that is). This review is based on only two games that I've played in, so people who have played Wild Warfare for a lot longer than I have will probably be able to form a better review than the one you're reading right now.

This review has been slightly edited in regards to the game now being free to play but many of the issues still stand currently.

I've found Wild Warfare heavily reminding me of arena-shooters such as Unreal tournament, and that in itself brings back many happy memories, memories that I hope to make in Wild Warfare. Unfortunately there are a few issues in the current version of this game that prevent me from outright recommending it to anyone, and I hope these issues get fixed soon (or at the very least tweaked to be a little more bearable then they are now).

Starting with some of the pros I found in my short playthrough:

Map selection in Wild Warfare is small, but the maps do feel nice and and are well-designed (for the most part, there is one exception with the current CTF map with jump-pads at the back of each base, which makes for relatively quick captures and seems to be very infuriating to players, going off by what I see in their discussion board). The maps aren't too large as to make finding other players impossible and there are several jump-pads around the maps, which speeds up travelling around these maps significantly, so you shouldn't be without someone to shoot at for long in a game.

The music in the game sounds nice, the artwork in the game is cute and inviting. Not much more to say here (mostly because I know next to nothing about music and art).

One of the things I especially liked was the fact that when you level up, you can get keys to open crates, which makes a huge difference (to me, anyway). I really hope this stays, as it offers some customization options for free to play players, which this game is supposedly going to be, though I don't see the option for free to play on steam yet (Though it seems you can play a browser-based version for free at Hyperhippo.ca).

One thing to note to parents looking at this game: Yes, there is no blood and gore or foul language, so if for some reason you want to introduce a young one to shooters, then you probably want to pick this up. Bear in mind though that this isn't accounting for any foul words that may come from strangers online.

Has a decent variety of game modes with another on the way it seems.

Seems to perform well on computers that have low specs (I have one terrible rig, so finding games that run on it is a blessing).

Onto some cons I found while playing:

What you see is what you get on your class. There are currently three classes in the game, and each has a different weapon; The engineer has a wrench, the heavy has a minigun, and the striker has a burst assault rifle. That's it. That's all they got. Weapon selection is not very big at this moment in time, though it does make it relatively simple to easily glance at a furry critter's hands (paws, for those that want to get technical with it) and look at the only weapon they have.

Bullet speed is slow, which slows down the pace of the game quite a bit for the firearms at anything beyond 'medium-range', which may not be a particularly bad thing as it encourages you to get closer to land shots easier, but a slight increase in bullet speed would be welcome.

There's no way to crouch in the game, which I didn't find as too big a deal since weapons don't have any recoil at all, but it's something to be noted.

You can't make your own servers at this time.

There are exploitable bugs and glitches that can seriously break the flow of a game (there appears to be an auto-firing bug, which happened quite a bit for me), which I hope are fixed soon.

Servers aren't the best, you'll see players floating in the sky and you can get hit by the engineer's wrench when they're a few feet away and nowhere near melee range. You won't have to worry about the servers, however, unless you can find a game with people. Not many people are currently online at a time, so it'll take awhile for you to find a server with people playing on it sometimes. However, with the game now being free to play, I expect a few servers with people in them, so perhaps the game population will increase in due time.

Classes aren't balanced at this time, with the heavy being underpowered, the striker being balanced, and the engineer being overpowered (at least, when it came to CTF, unsure of how the engineer performs in the other modes).

While not a con, something I'd like to bring up is competition from other games. When reading about the game it sounds quite a bit like Team Fortress two, doesn't it? It even has hats. Yes, I'm aware Team Fortress two doesn't have vehicles but otherwise it seems like it'll be very much the same. Wild Warfare also references Team Fortress two through an achievement, so it's safe to say that they are at least aware of Team fortress two (then again you'd have to be under a rock not to). While I don't expect it to ever overtake Team Fortress two in terms of popularity, I do think it'll at least get a stable community of players, especially since it's also a free to play game that has a slight Team Fortress two vibe at first glance. I'm looking forward to how things will turn out!

Well, that's about all I can say from my two games worth of experience. As stated earlier I cannot recommend the game in its current state, however I do enjoy playing it and would like to in the future. I can't give a definite answer to if you should buy this game or not, but currently, I am content with most of the things I see, and I only hope this game gets better.

Wild Warfare is one of those Early Access titles that came out too early. The content is too bare to really call it a game. Thankfully it is free to play, otherwise I would've just dismissed this game and called it a waste of money. Instead, I see it as a waste of time. The combat is boring and has an identity crisis of what it truly wants to be. It's part Quake/Unreal Tournament, part Class-based warfare, but it doesn't do justice to either of the two. It isn't as fast based as Quake/Unreal Tournament and it doesn't offer enough diversity between the 3 current classes to really feel like a new experience each time you select a class.

The map design is plain and offers the basic jump-pads of an arena style shooter, as well as the med-kits. However, it lacks any extra weapons to pick up so you are stuck with the only weapon your class possesses.

I would like to see this game evolve into something greater, but as it stands now, it isn't even worth the download.

Yes, dearest review readers. At this time, it's buggy. The loadout boxes and key thing is weird, and almost seems rushed. The CPU plant enemies don't exactly play nice, nor do they act as they should, (I doubt they're supposed to move that fast,) and finally, the lag is ridiculous! But, all in all, excellent gaming experience in my opinion!

It's got potential; a lot more potential than certain games lurking around Steam, and for what it's worth, I can already tell that this is gonna be one addicting game later on down the road. How could it not? You get beaten to death by bunnies, shoot at roadents, capture flags, and go wild!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is pretty fun! Don't look at the playtime, I got more playtime, like 5 hours, due the fact i was playing via web version. First you got 3 unique classes which totally difference from each other, the levels are not many, still early access, but they are quite fun. You have many obstacles as some berry like creatures to chase and eat you, exploding crates which you can use to blow the enemy, power ups, hot streams which shoot you up, similar to jumps on quake 3 which makes game pretty fun.

Deathmatch is fun, because of the neutral enemies, those are quite nasty and hard to run from, but they gives you points too, so if you are having skills, you can win the game counting on them.

Capture the flag, there you have yuge robot to control which helps you to support the team or guard your flag, you have speed ups many places to barricade yourself  and guard, many place to stuck enemy into a trap between exploding crates.

Team Deathmatch, again differs from usual gameplay, you should just check the game and see that it looks more fun than the videos.

What is expected.
As far as i know new classes, maps, customizations and friend invitations are planned. So I'm expecting good stuff from the game now.

Bad things here.
The only drawbacks, the game crashes at me somehow before joining, happened several times. No clan-tags and avatar support and nothing was mentioned for those. Needs more perks, double damage, double health, etc, which will really make the gameplay more intensive.
No LAN support or dedicated server announced.

Pay to play - pay to win?
Nah, the game at it's current stage is free to play and has no microtrasactions, they stated that they are planning to add payment methods and I hope that will not overpower some players compared to another when product is finished in the future, because it will disbalance it greatly which is not cool thing for shooter.

Gameplay goes well!
The game plays smooth, characters are not lagging out or glitching into objects despite the edgy areas, it has nice dynamics, movements are good, aiming is very nicely done. Sometimes it takes quite much of skills to bring down your enemy as they dodges your shooting pretty good too.
The only thing that nagged me about shooting from higher place is that your shooting hits the ground so you should expose yourself from your cover to kill someone, still that is not something bad, you should just pay more caution on your cover then.

I recommend the game, especially because lack of pay to joy, it is pretty fun in the current state and I really hope they to keep it that way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In short, Wild Warfare aims to be Team Fortress 2 with furry animals.  That lofty goal is however still aways off.  What you'll find at this early stage in development is some fairly crude stuff.  Notwithstanding, I've had fun with what I've played.

As with every Early Access game, however, what you're paying for is potential (paying if you buy the DLC, that is).  Right now I have to ask myself whether the devs aren't perhaps wasting a lot of effort with this game.  After all, we already have Team Fortress 2.  Why do a clone?  I would suppose the simplest answer to this question being -- why not do a clone?  If one thing is successful, does that presuppose that someone else shouldn't try to do the same thing and try to beat the original at its own game?  I mean, that's the core of virtually all business, isn't it?  All businesses try to do something better which others are already doing.

Since this is Early Access, prepare for some rough patches, including:

- few players
- few maps
- maps are overly simplistic, crude and small
- general lack of detail (and personality) with regards to character models
- low resolution textures
- gun models take up far too much visual space, blocking your view
- only three playable classes
- and they are horribly unbalanced
- stock music which doesn't fit the theme or the action

Right now, during Winter Sale 2014, the DLC pack is €0,41.  I've decided to buy a few and hand them out to friends to try and get the community going.  If the developers buck the Early Access trend and actually make this into a game worth playing, i.e. a product that rivals Team Fortress 2 for its polish and accessibility (while embracing the competitive edge lacking in TF2's model), then we'll be on to a winner.

In my opinion, there is a market for a competitive FPS starring cutesy animals wielding big guns (provided the guns don't block half the screen).  Now let's hope Hyper Hippo Prods. don't screw up their particular stab at that market.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you would have asked me a while ago, I would have recommended Wild Warfare without hesitation. But things have changed quite a bit recently.

Let's start off with a history lesson. Wild Warfare started off as a game called Mech Mice Academy (MMA). It was an interesting little FPS built off of a modded engine. As the game developed, more people started playing. But then something happened. The game went on kickstarter and transitioned into Wild Warfare. It launched on Steam Greenlight and then eventually released on steam. However, some of the MMA players didn't like the transition to Wild Warfare and left.

The player base has been very erratic over the past few months. Shortly after the game launched on Steam, there were 105 people playing this game at once. Since then, it has decreased. 105 was the most ever Steam players at one time Wild Warfare has ever seen, which is very sad, since this game had and still possibly has so much potential. The community is so small now that the developers have recently removed the server selection option to keep all the players together on the same servers. Sometimes this makes it very difficult to be on the same game as your friends.

There is no matchmaking whatsoever, which is a pro and a con at the same time. The pro: Since the community is so small, it helps keep the servers filled up. The con: You could be a level 1 playing on a server with 3 level 50s. There is a HUGE gap in the skill of players right now. Most players are either a complete noob or extremely skilled.

I was informed recently that the developers are putting this game off to the side and we will recieve few, if any, updates unless more people start playing. Realistically, I doubt that this is going to happen. The player base has been dwindling at about the same rate it is growing, sometimes going up and sometimes going down. Sadly, the general trend of the player base is down. However, putting this game to the side is just going to kill it. Only the games that recieve regular patches keep a consistent player base. If the game isn't dead now, it's gonna be soon.

The direction Wild Warfare has gone is very sad, since it could have been real good. Maybe even the best. But as much as I like this game and continue to play it, I simply can't recommend it to new players. Not in its current state.

This gets a recommendation from me, but with an asterisk. This is an incredibly fun, addicting, and hilarious arena style first person shooter. Each animal is essentially a different class, the bear is a big lumbering enemy and has a heavy machine gun and lots of health. The raccoon (my personal favorite) is pretty quick and has a 3-shot burst rifle and half of the bear's health. The bunny (which is terrifying to run into) is the fastest of the classes, can double jump, has the least health, and is melee only. The classes play off one another really well and feel very balanced, the maps are well designed, movement and combat are very slick and feel very smooth... But now I have to talk about that asterisk.

Getting into a game is next to impossible, you need to have friends who will buy and play this game with you or else you're going to have a tough time. Not only that, but my friends and I had issues joining the only server with players on it because every time we would try our games would freeze and crash. The game feels pretty bare-bones at this point in development, and if nothing else is done with it I find it kind of hard to recommend. However, if the developers keep on working on the game and actually finish it then I can't recommend the game enough. This game has insane potential, it's just good old fashioned FUN with a competitive edge.

And a message to the developers, the game's options menu is kind of... Unfortunate. Particularly in the audio department. Rather than having an on/off switch for the in game sounds and music, a slider for each should be implemented. I loved playing with music, but when I had it on it was too loud for me to hear my friends so I had to turn it off.

TL;DR - Very fun game, needs some work.

This is not a bad title, it is just very under-implemented right now. What does that mean?

It means that the premise is pretty solid: cartoony animals duke it out shooter style, with each animal being it's own class and filling certain niches on the team. There's even a big mech already, so that's good. And the guns looks more or elss like Nerf guns, which is the kind of hi-tech blocky look I can get behind. :)

The down side is, there are only three classes... and each class has exactly 1 weapon. Slow heavy badger(?) with a chaingun, middle-speed average-sized raccoon with a 3-round-burst rifle, and a rabbit with a wrench (he is called the engineer, but cannot build or repair things that I know of). So, the makings of some good class warfare here, but there are not yet enough thigns to differeniant them.

Potential, though. Lots of that! You can already imagine in your mind what future classes they might add, and it's not as if there is a lack of inspiration for extra gear. There is a crate system, which as far as I can tell, is cosmetic-only items and I don't believe you can buy them: crates drop from players, and keys are given as you rank up (I could be mistaken, but that's where it seems to be right now, which is good).

So hey, this is a free-to-play early access game. That means you won't pay anything but your trime to give this a download and shoot some stuff up. I think that this game is worth following, as it has the potential to shape up into something really fun and relatively unique in the world of shooters. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you would have asked me a while ago, I would have recommended Wild Warfare without hesitation. But things have changed quite a bit recently.

Let's start off with a history lesson. Wild Warfare started off as a game called Mech Mice Academy (MMA). It was an interesting little FPS built off of a modded engine. As the game developed, more people started playing. But then something happened. The game went on kickstarter and transitioned into Wild Warfare. It launched on Steam Greenlight and then eventually released on steam. However, some of the MMA players didn't like the transition to Wild Warfare and left.

The player base has been very erratic over the past few months. Shortly after the game launched on Steam, there were 105 people playing this game at once. Since then, it has decreased. 105 was the most ever Steam players at one time Wild Warfare has ever seen, which is very sad, since this game had and still possibly has so much potential. The community is so small now that the developers have recently removed the server selection option to keep all the players together on the same servers. Sometimes this makes it very difficult to be on the same game as your friends.

There is no matchmaking whatsoever, which is a pro and a con at the same time. The pro: Since the community is so small, it helps keep the servers filled up. The con: You could be a level 1 playing on a server with 3 level 50s. There is a HUGE gap in the skill of players right now. Most players are either a complete noob or extremely skilled.

I was informed recently that the developers are putting this game off to the side and we will recieve few, if any, updates unless more people start playing. Realistically, I doubt that this is going to happen. The player base has been dwindling at about the same rate it is growing, sometimes going up and sometimes going down. Sadly, the general trend of the player base is down. However, putting this game to the side is just going to kill it. Only the games that recieve regular patches keep a consistent player base. If the game isn't dead now, it's gonna be soon.

The direction Wild Warfare has gone is very sad, since it could have been real good. Maybe even the best. But as much as I like this game and continue to play it, I simply can't recommend it to new players. Not in its current state.

Horribly buggy and hasn't update in 2 or so years after watching a youtube video on it. Like TF2 dumbed down, basically. Each class has one weapon, raccoon 'striker' shoots 3 shots 1 damage each and can aim down sights 4 hp, rabbit 'engineer' has a wrench and whacks people with it for 2 damage each and has 3 hp may or may not run fast, bear 'heavy' that has a minigun that can overheat with bullets that deal 1 damage each moves slowly and has 8 hp.

There are different modes but you can't mode select, it choses for you. FFA, team deathmatch, and capture the flag from what I saw. Vehicles are 'level locked' which basically means if you didn't play enough matches before entering the match with a vehicle you can't use it. The game feels floaty, I could barely hit someone going up a ramp in a straight line.

In the capture the flag mode, people can pick up a speed power up before picking the flag up to get it away faster, but not with the flag equipped. You can't drop things either, as far as I can tell from the 'rebindable keys.' There is no chat, may have removed it? In FFA mode there was a snail I picked up as far as I could tell did nothing, and since I couldn't drop it, I threw myself into the lava.

The AI in the game is dumb, and if you sneak up behind them you have a 50 50 they won't turn around and attack you back, but since most of this game is killing people by sneaking up behind them (3 shot burst for quick kill as a striker, hitting them with the wrench as the bunny, doing a quick gun down as a heavy) there's rarely a time to pick a fair fight by going up in front about it due to low HP and high damage.

The only redeeming factor I could see is the cosmetics, which you randomly got per level some keys to open crates that dropped from enemies. I didn't see a cash shop other than the DLC they had on the store, which wasn't too highly priced either. I guess the main reason this hasn't been updated in 2 years is due to no money and being FTP, but still isn't worth playing imo.

Early Access Review

In the short time I've played this game, I can tell you a lot about it.

Wild Warfare is a FPS game featuring multiple classes, all inspired by cartoonish animal characters. Players participate in team-based objectives and large maps, with multiple game modes and a different animal for every class type.

This game is a diamond in the rough that REALLY shines. It could do with a few more updates like new maps, gamemodes and maybe characters even though they are pretty perfect already. They are well balanced and each have their strong suits. The customization options are absolutely brilliant. Facepaint, bow ties, top hats and many more and they're pretty easy to unlock to! Wild Warfare isn't without flaws, (which game isn't?) but the satisfaction of killing another player is immense and pays off really well. It nails that one more go feeling and can get quite intense in certain gamemodes.
Talking about gamemodes, some of them could be improved. The worst is the Snail Gamemode where a player can collect the snail which gives them one point per second. This can be quite an annoying mode because people always win by a landslide. So watch out for that.

Overall this unusual and unique FPS game is a great game to spice up your free time. It's nowhere near a P2W either. You'll be on the edge of your seats in the intense battles. What are you waiting for? Go download that game!

Early Access Review

Current Review:

Wild Warfare is one of those Early Access titles that came out too early. The content is too bare to really call it a game. Thankfully it is free to play, otherwise I would've just dismissed this game and called it a waste of money. Instead, I see it as a waste of time. There is very little content in this game, and it's in very early alpha. I find it a poor choice to release a public access to such a tile that has yet to offer anything really meaningful.

The combat is boring and has an identity crisis of what it truly wants to be. It's part Quake/Unreal Tournament, part Class-based warfare, but it doesn't do justice to either of the two. It isn't as fast based as Quake/Unreal Tournament and it doesn't offer enough diversity between the 3 current classes to really feel like a new experience each time you select a class.

The map design is plain and offers the basic jump-pads of an arena style shooter, as well as the med-kits. However, it lacks any extra weapons to pick up so you are stuck with the only weapon your class possesses.

I would like to see this game evolve into something greater, but as it stands now, it isn't even worth the download.

I enjoy this game because of its simple First Person Shooter style. This game is all you can want in a game. Unlike other FPS games I play, this game has a rankup system. It is balanced so that the better you are, the higher you get. It doesn't matter who you are playing as long as you are better, or if you arent, can practice to get better. This silly game is actually very fun and addicting. To be honest, I know some people that have parents in which do not allow them to play M rated games such as most FPS games. This game doesn't have any factors that would make this game really that violent. Basically what I'm trying to say is that this game is incredible and enjoyable not to mention addicting, and is the perfect pick for those seeking another free FPS game. I do want to mention that I do not like the lack of players. If this game were much more popular this game would be epic. Some people have been claiming about bugs, but as far as i'm concerned, there really arent many. I do want to mention that if you are a fan of Team Fortress 2, take the 3 classes and match them with this:
- Striker: Basically Scout - Runs Fast has a good gun
- Heavy: Heavy from TF2 - Runs slowly with heavy weapon and is very fat
- Engineer: Engineer from TF2 - Runs moderate speed although can't build sentries or anything - just carries a wrench
Basically, if you are used to the gameplay of TF2, this game should be an easy adaptation. One other thing is that the gamemodes are sometimes too short to do what you want. I would much enjoy it if the folks at Hyper Hippo would make CTF maybe a round based game instead of a time based game. Same with Snail Hunter. One other thing is that you should consider the $4.99 DLC pack for this game to get you some cool cosmetics to make you look like a true Wild Warfare MLG Pro. Bottom line is, this is a great free to play FPS game that i'm sure you'll probably enjoy playing with other people on the game, and your friends! Luckily for me, i'm already occupied with this game too much...You'll see me eventually I bet.

Early Access Review

pros:
- really cute characters
- casual yet competitive gameplay
- easy to level up (I'm already level 9 after just an hour of gameplay)
- each character has their own advantages and disadvantages
- nice open maps
- great graphics (played on max settings, beautiful and 1366 x 768)

cons:
- huge framerate drop/lag when too many people are shooting at once at the player
- only 3 maps :(
- crappy server connection system, which doesn't allow you to connect to specific friends in games
- inconsistent server connections (after matches, my friend and I kept getting put on different servers in the same region)
- inconsistent loading screens (after matches, you never know if you'll go back to the loadout screen or the main menu)
- not enough U.S. players, all maps we found that were heavily populated were the EU servers
- no chat feature in-game
- all rounds are timed
- no ability to set up a private server
- quick game mode is the only playing mode


Overall: This game is more so demo or proof of concept length than Early Access length. If this is showing a more in-depth version of the game available for pre-purchase (it's not now but at some point I assume it was) then it should be much longer to make it worthwhile. Otherwise, it should just be called a demo. It would be cool if there were a story mode where you actually get to go to new maps after you reach a certain level. It's nice for a free game, but this has been in Early Access for a while so there's no telling if work on this game will ever be resumed, but it's certainly something I'd put my money towards once finished.

Early Access Review

pros:
- really cute characters
- casual yet competitive gameplay
- easy to level up (I'm already level 9 after just an hour of gameplay)
- each character has their own advantages and disadvantages
- nice open maps
- great graphics (played on max settings, beautiful and 1366 x 768)

cons:
- huge framerate drop/lag when too many people are shooting at once at the player
- only 3 maps :(
- crappy server connection system, which doesn't allow you to connect to specific friends in games
- inconsistent server connections (after matches, my friend and I kept getting put on different servers in the same region)
- inconsistent loading screens (after matches, you never know if you'll go back to the loadout screen or the main menu)
- not enough U.S. players, all maps we found that were heavily populated were the EU servers
- no chat feature in-game
- all rounds are timed
- no ability to set up a private server
- quick game mode is the only playing mode


Overall: This game is more so demo or proof of concept length than Early Access length. If this is showing a more in-depth version of the game available for pre-purchase (it's not now but at some point I assume it was) then it should be much longer to make it worthwhile. Otherwise, it should just be called a demo. It would be cool if there were a story mode where you actually get to go to new maps after you reach a certain level. It's nice for a free game, but this has been in Early Access for a while so there's no telling if work on this game will ever be resumed, but it's certainly something I'd put my money towards once finished.
